data.text: How Long Does Chain/Sprocket Last when Bike Touring?

How long does your chain/sprocket last? I've run through my last set within 2000km/2months and I find that bit devastating. I would have assumed I keep the parts quite clean and with neither too much nor too little grease on, yes I do go 80% in highest gear but I've done worse things with my previous bike (eg, setting off in the highest gear on full load) where a set of chain/sprocket lastet easily more than 15k. I'm riding a 90s MTB, it feels bit ridiculous to spend as much on parts every two months as the bike did cost me second hand in the first place, but if nowadays that's how short the parts live, getting a sparkling new bike wouldn't make much sense either? Pic for attention from my last trip across Germany and the weekly ride to my garden

I've got 15,000 km from a new cassette and chainrings. I changed the chain approximately every 5,000 km. This was on my longest tour. Since then generally do a shorter 5,000 km tour once a year then use the same setup until I depart the next year and replace everything. I am not as aware of the distance I'm putting on it when just doing recreational rides around town.

data.author: Vero Wonders

data.text: In that case it appears that there might be something seriously wrong with the bike or drive train. As you bought the bike second hand, it is possible that the frame is bent. If the bike has been re-painted it has probably been in an accident. If the drive rings are not in line with the cogs (even a couple of degrees out) the chain will not run over the cogs freely, but will rub on the sides. Or it could be a problem with the bottom bracket, causing the crank to run slightly skew. I am not saying that is definitly the case, but you should get the bike checked out.

data.text: Then it is possible that the parts used may not have been fitted properly, or may not be indexed correctly. Ask a bike shop to check it, if you can tell them about the short life. It might just be an alignment issue. Also get them to check that the crank is lined up and running straight.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Something's not right. Without seeing pics to diagnose I'll just through out some ideas. 1) You can check chain ring wear visually by looking at the teeth. If they look like shark fins, replace. I look at mine every time I clean my chain. 2) Check chains with a chain checker tool. You should be able to get several thousand miles out of a chain. Check it every time you clean your chain. I heard from a mechainic that 1x setups eat up chains due to crazy chain lines but haven't confirmed that personnally. 3) Rear cassettes rarely need replacing if you take care of your chain rings and chain. Just keep 'em clean. Chains are about the most unfun of purchases so I hope something helps. Good luck!
data.author: Mike Schlacter
